newsitem.title: USA: Clinton looks to lease out space in U.S. oil reserve.
newsitem.headline: Clinton looks to lease out space in U.S. oil reserve.

text.p: President Clinton will seek permission to lease out space in the U.S. Strategic Petroleum Reserve to other countries in his budget proposal this week, an Energy Department official said Tuesday.

The five-year balanced budget package would include legislative authority to start leasing the extra space in the petroleum reserve's caverns in the 1999 fiscal year, which begins October 1998, he said.
The administration sought the same authority last year in legislation to reauthorize the law that governs use of the SPR, but Congress did not have time to debate the proposal.
The law must be renewed before October.
The reserve has a capacity of 750 million barrels, and currently holds 565 million barrels of oil.
The department official did not disclose how much money the administration estimated it would earn from leasing out the space.
The most likely users of SPR space would be oil consuming countries who need emergency reserves, U.S. officials said.
They said with most producing countries, except Saudi Arabia, pumping near capacity to meet market demand, they would have little incentive to store their oil in the SPR.
